feature_title: Plural of objects coming in pairs
feature_description: Ibragimov [@ibragimov2004: 52, 126, 149, 152, 172] suggests that some dialects use special pluralization strategies for words denoting objects usually coming in pairs (eyes, legs, etc.). Such plurals are formed from singular absolutive (*ul* ‘eye’, *ʁil* ‘leg’) with formant *-ab*, e.g. *ulab* ‘eyes’, *ʁilab* ‘legs’. Other dialects have regular plurals, e.g. *ulabɨr* ‘eyes’, *ʁilabɨr* ‘legs’. We collected forms of these two nouns using three stimuli: ‘eyes’ (citation context), ‘She has beautiful eyes’ and ‘My legs hurt’. In the case of ‘eyes’, the first reaction always was the form *ulabɨr*. We asked whether the form *ulab* is possible. The map shows the results: **OK ulab** — the form *ulab* is possible, **NO ulab** — it is impossible. As for ‘leg’, we almost always got the form *ʁilabɨr* as the first reaction, except for Myukhrek, where the first reaction was *ʁilab* (but *ʁilabɨr* was also deemed possible). The map shows the results: **OK ʁilab** — the form *ʁilab* is possible, **NO ʁilab** — it is impossible, **ʁilab as first reaction** — a label for Myukhrek only, where, unlike other dialects, this form was the first reaction.
name: Сара

feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘brother’ is either *šuˤ* (attested only in Khnov), *šugu* (attested only in Ikhrek) or *šu* (elsewhere). The attested variants of the plural marker include *-be* (and its phonetic variants) and *-jmar*. The latter forms either a simple — *šugu-jmar* (in Ikhrek), or a double marked plural — *šu-be-jmar* (and its phonetic variants). The map shows the distribution of the variants.
name: Сара
comment: фарингализации вроде нет, уь тоже нет, б мягкий

long_periods_outside: лет 30 жил в разных местах в России

feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘goat’ is either *cʼihʲ* or *cʼij* (see feature @). The plural absolutive can be either regular: *cʼiher*, *cʼihe* and *cʼijmar* (and their phonetic variants) or irregular: *cʼuhuler* (and its phonetic variants). Depending on the village, in our data only the regular forms are attested, only irregular ones, or both types of forms may coexist.
name: Саидмагомед
long_periods_outside: лет 30 жил в разных местах в России
comment: ц1угьулар - мелкий рогатый скот с шерстью

feature_title: Plural of objects coming in pairs
feature_description: Ibragimov [@ibragimov2004: 52, 126, 149, 152, 172] suggests that some dialects use special pluralization strategies for words denoting objects usually coming in pairs (eyes, legs, etc.). Such plurals are formed from singular absolutive (*ul* ‘eye’, *ʁil* ‘leg’) with formant *-ab*, e.g. *ulab* ‘eyes’, *ʁilab* ‘legs’. Other dialects have regular plurals, e.g. *ulabɨr* ‘eyes’, *ʁilabɨr* ‘legs’. We collected forms of these two nouns using three stimuli: ‘eyes’ (citation context), ‘She has beautiful eyes’ and ‘My legs hurt’. In the case of ‘eyes’, the first reaction always was the form *ulabɨr*. We asked whether the form *ulab* is possible. The map shows the results: **OK ulab** — the form *ulab* is possible, **NO ulab** — it is impossible. As for ‘leg’, we almost always got the form *ʁilabɨr* as the first reaction, except for Myukhrek, where the first reaction was *ʁilab* (but *ʁilabɨr* was also deemed possible). The map shows the results: **OK ʁilab** — the form *ʁilab* is possible, **NO ʁilab** — it is impossible, **ʁilab as first reaction** — a label for Myukhrek only, where, unlike other dialects, this form was the first reaction.
name: Сара

name: Ахмад
long_periods_outside: в 16 лет переехал в Махачкалу, каждый год приезжает, до 21 года в Москве жил

feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘cow’ varies as following: *zer*,  *zʲer*, *zär* and *zʲär* (see feature @). The plural absolutive is irregular in that it loses /r/ of the root: *zebɨr* (and its phonetic variants: *zʲebɨr*, *zʲäbɨr*) and *zʲebir* / *zebir*. The map shows the variation in plural forms.
name: Сара

feature_description: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘cow’ varies as following: *zer*,  *zʲer*, *zär* and *zʲär* (see feature @). The plural absolutive is irregular in that it loses /r/ of the root: *zebɨr* (and its phonetic variants: *zʲebɨr*, *zʲäbɨr*) and *zʲebir* / *zebir*. The map shows the variation in plural forms.

feature_title: Ergative marker type of attributive singular
feature_description: Likewise to nouns (see @feature), we classified the variants of the ergative marker of attributives into r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG) and non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG). We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the attributives, respectively.
name: Сара
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу
comment: ху1л'ахнов (можно ды), джик'дынов, без ды нельзя

feature_title: Vowel presence in ergative marker of attributive singular
feature_description:
Apart from the ergative marker of attributives being of r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG) or of non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG), it may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG) the final vowel. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* (little-ATTR-OBL-DAT) and also see @feature), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.
name: Сара
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу
comment: ху1л'ахнов (можно ды), джик'дынов, без ды нельзя

feature_title: Oblique stem formant of attributive in ergative singular
feature_description: The maps show how the oblique stem of attributive referring to humans is formed. We asked two contexts with three attributives: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. Three variants of stem formants were attested: *nij* / *ni* (in Rutul, Kufa, Kiche and Kala), *na* (in Shinaz and Khnov) and *naw* / *now* / *nɨw* / *nu* (elsewhere). For example, we got form *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* (lame-OBL-ERG), cf. with absolutive form *alkʼa-d* (lame-ATTR); the formant *-nɨw-* is used to form an oblique stem.
name: Сара
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу
comment: ху1л'ахнов (можно ды), джик'дынов, без ды нельзя

Apart from the ergative marker of attributives being of r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG) or of non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG), it may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG) the final vowel. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* (little-ATTR-OBL-DAT) and also see @feature), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.
name: Айшат
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Oblique stem formant of attributive in ergative singular
feature_description: The maps show how the oblique stem of attributive referring to humans is formed. We asked two contexts with three attributives: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. Three variants of stem formants were attested: *nij* / *ni* (in Rutul, Kufa, Kiche and Kala), *na* (in Shinaz and Khnov) and *naw* / *now* / *nɨw* / *nu* (elsewhere). For example, we got form *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* (lame-OBL-ERG), cf. with absolutive form *alkʼa-d* (lame-ATTR); the formant *-nɨw-* is used to form an oblique stem.
name: Айшат
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_description:
Apart from the ergative marker of attributives being of r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG) or of non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG), it may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG) the final vowel. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* (little-ATTR-OBL-DAT) and also see @feature), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.
name: Сабир

feature_title: Oblique stem formant of attributive in ergative singular
feature_description: The maps show how the oblique stem of attributive referring to humans is formed. We asked two contexts with three attributives: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. Three variants of stem formants were attested: *nij* / *ni* (in Rutul, Kufa, Kiche and Kala), *na* (in Shinaz and Khnov) and *naw* / *now* / *nɨw* / *nu* (elsewhere). For example, we got form *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* (lame-OBL-ERG), cf. with absolutive form *alkʼa-d* (lame-ATTR); the formant *-nɨw-* is used to form an oblique stem.

feature_title: Vowel presence in ergative marker of attributive singular
feature_description:
Apart from the ergative marker of attributives being of r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG) or of non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG), it may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG) the final vowel. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* (little-ATTR-OBL-DAT) and also see @feature), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.
name: магамед
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Oblique stem formant of attributive in ergative singular
feature_description: The maps show how the oblique stem of attributive referring to humans is formed. We asked two contexts with three attributives: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. Three variants of stem formants were attested: *nij* / *ni* (in Rutul, Kufa, Kiche and Kala), *na* (in Shinaz and Khnov) and *naw* / *now* / *nɨw* / *nu* (elsewhere). For example, we got form *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* (lame-OBL-ERG), cf. with absolutive form *alkʼa-d* (lame-ATTR); the formant *-nɨw-* is used to form an oblique stem.
name: магамед
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Oblique stem formant of attributive in ergative singular
feature_description: The maps show how the oblique stem of attributive referring to humans is formed. We asked two contexts with three attributives: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. Three variants of stem formants were attested: *nij* / *ni* (in Rutul, Kufa, Kiche and Kala), *na* (in Shinaz and Khnov) and *naw* / *now* / *nɨw* / *nu* (elsewhere). For example, we got form *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* (lame-OBL-ERG), cf. with absolutive form *alkʼa-d* (lame-ATTR); the formant *-nɨw-* is used to form an oblique stem.
name: Канбар
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Ergative marker type of attributive singular
feature_description: Likewise to nouns (see @feature), we classified the variants of the ergative marker of attributives into r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG) and non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG). We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the attributives, respectively.
name: муратхан
residence_place: сейчас в Каспийске — после школы, приезжает в куфа
stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_title: Vowel presence in ergative marker of attributive singular
feature_description:
Apart from the ergative marker of attributives being of r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG) or of non-r-type (e.g. *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG), it may either contain (*alkʼa-nu-ra* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ* lame-OBL-ERG) or lack (*alkʼa-nu-r* lame-OBL-ERG, *alkʼa-now-Ø* lame-OBL-ERG) the final vowel. We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

N. B. In Shinaz it is considered that vowel in non-r-type ergative marker is ABSENT, because the oblique stem formant is *-na-* (cf. dative case form *kʼaʔa-dɨ-na-s* (little-ATTR-OBL-DAT) and also see @feature), that is, there is no evident ergative marker.

stimuli: [Пришло два человека:] Высокий собирал яблоки, а низкий держал лестницу

feature_description: We classified the variants of the ergative marker into r-type (e.g. *balʁu-ra* fish.OBL-ERG) and non-r-type (e.g. *gagaj-e* uncle-ERG, *gagaj-Ø* uncle-ERG). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: Сара

feature_description: Apart from the ergative marker being of r-type (*balʁu-ra* fish.OBL-ERG) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* uncle-ERG, *gagaj-Ø* uncle-ERG), it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* fish.OBL-ERG, *gagaj-e* uncle-ERG) or lack (*balʁu-r* fish.OBL-ERG, *gagaj-Ø* uncle-ERG) the final vowel. This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* (fish.OBL-ERG), we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.

We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.

feature_description: Apart from the ergative marker being of r-type (*balʁu-ra* fish.OBL-ERG) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* uncle-ERG, *gagaj-Ø* uncle-ERG), it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* fish.OBL-ERG, *gagaj-e* uncle-ERG) or lack (*balʁu-r* fish.OBL-ERG, *gagaj-Ø* uncle-ERG) the final vowel. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* (fish.OBL-ERG), we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.
name: аскер

feature_description: We classified the variants of the ergative marker into r-type (e.g. *balʁu-ra* fish.OBL-ERG) and non-r-type (e.g. *gagaj-e* uncle-ERG, *gagaj-Ø* uncle-ERG). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: Мухтар
long_periods_outside: 5 лет учился в городе, ездил по всей России на соревнования
answer: дайеше куьмек' гьакьыры йас хал гьакьас

We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: Ахмад
long_periods_outside: в 16 лет переехал в Махачкалу, каждый год приезжает, до 21 года в Москве жил

feature_description: Apart from the ergative marker being of r-type (*balʁu-ra* fish.OBL-ERG) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* uncle-ERG, *gagaj-Ø* uncle-ERG), it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* fish.OBL-ERG, *gagaj-e* uncle-ERG) or lack (*balʁu-r* fish.OBL-ERG, *gagaj-Ø* uncle-ERG) the final vowel. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: Фарида
answer: балугъмаш лииъыры баладбыр дыдар, OK балугъмаше

The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.
name: мафият

The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.
name: Муслимат
long_periods_outside: в Махачкале закончила университет - филологический факультет

The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.
name: муратхан
residence_place: сейчас в Каспийске — после школы, приезжает в куфа

feature_description: Apart from the ergative marker being of r-type (*balʁu-ra* fish.OBL-ERG) or non-r-type (*gagaj-e* uncle-ERG, *gagaj-Ø* uncle-ERG), it may either contain (*balʁu-ra* fish.OBL-ERG, *gagaj-e* uncle-ERG) or lack (*balʁu-r* fish.OBL-ERG, *gagaj-Ø* uncle-ERG) the final vowel. This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker's first reaction was *balʁu-ra* (fish.OBL-ERG), we asked if it is possible to say *balʁu-r*, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.
name: муратхан
residence_place: сейчас в Каспийске — после школы, приезжает в куфа

feature_description: The maps show the variation of the comitative marker as represented in two elicited contexts: ‘Rasul went hunting with a dog’ and ‘Rasul went to Makhachkala by car’. The markers attested are the following: *-kʷan*, *-kan*, *-xʷan*, *-xan*, *-fan*. The variants *-kʷan* and *-kan* are attested in Kina, Luchek, Amsar and Kiche, *-fan* is attested in Ikhrek and Khnov, *-xan* is attested in Ikhrek and Rutul. The last variant, *-xʷan* is attested everywhere except Kina, Luchek and Khnov. The label OTHER is used if the meaning is expressed by means other than a nominal suffix but by a construction with a locative copula: *χana*, *χan*, *xʷana*.
name: Сара
stimuli: Расул пошел на охоту с собакой

feature_description: The maps show the variation of the comitative marker as represented in two elicited contexts: ‘Rasul went hunting with a dog’ and ‘Rasul went to Makhachkala by car’. The markers attested are the following: *-kʷan*, *-kan*, *-xʷan*, *-xan*, *-fan*. The variants *-kʷan* and *-kan* are attested in Kina, Luchek, Amsar and Kiche, *-fan* is attested in Ikhrek and Khnov, *-xan* is attested in Ikhrek and Rutul. The last variant, *-xʷan* is attested everywhere except Kina, Luchek and Khnov. The label OTHER is used if the meaning is expressed by means other than a nominal suffix but by a construction with a locative copula: *χana*, *χan*, *xʷana*.

stimuli: Расул пошел на охоту с собакой

feature_description: The maps show the variation of the comitative marker as represented in two elicited contexts: ‘Rasul went hunting with a dog’ and ‘Rasul went to Makhachkala by car’. The markers attested are the following: *-kʷan*, *-kan*, *-xʷan*, *-xan*, *-fan*. The variants *-kʷan* and *-kan* are attested in Kina, Luchek, Amsar and Kiche, *-fan* is attested in Ikhrek and Khnov, *-xan* is attested in Ikhrek and Rutul. The last variant, *-xʷan* is attested everywhere except Kina, Luchek and Khnov. The label OTHER is used if the meaning is expressed by means other than a nominal suffix but by a construction with a locative copula: *χana*, *χan*, *xʷana*.
name: феруза
schooling: школа в Рутуле до 9 класса, закончила там, училась в городе,
stimuli: Расул пошел на охоту с собакой

feature_description: Attributive marker can be either *-dɨ*, either *-d*. We asked nine contexts, six with the head ‘knife’: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in oblique case), ‘sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with a sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in oblique case), ‘my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in oblique case). And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.
name: Лейла

And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.

And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.

The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.

We asked nine contexts, six with the head ‘knife’: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in oblique case), ‘sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with a sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in oblique case), ‘my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in oblique case). And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.
name: Муслимат

We asked nine contexts, six with the head ‘knife’: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in oblique case), ‘sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with a sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in oblique case), ‘my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in oblique case). And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.
name: Канбар

feature_title: Possessor form in temporary possessive construction
feature_description: Temporary possessor is a participant that carries a possessum but who does not own it (cf. *I do not have your book with me*). We elicited two contexts: ‘Do not search for your passport, I have it’ and ‘Who has a pen?’. We considered the reaction to the first context as primary evidence. The maps show the forms of pronouns ‘I’ and ‘who’ in these contexts. The attested variants for ‘I’ include *zada*, *zadɨ*, *zad* and *zadːa*, and are never identical to the marking used in possessive predication (see feature @). The second context is probably ambiguous, because some consultants used the form (*halɨχda*) that was used in possessive predication, which we believe suggests “permanent” interpretation of the context with pragmatic inference of having it also here and now, such cases are labeled as OTHER. The attested variants for ‘who’ include *halda* and *haldɨ*.
name: Лейла

feature_title: Possessor form in temporary possessive construction
feature_description: Temporary possessor is a participant that carries a possessum but who does not own it (cf. *I do not have your book with me*). We elicited two contexts: ‘Do not search for your passport, I have it’ and ‘Who has a pen?’. We considered the reaction to the first context as primary evidence. The maps show the forms of pronouns ‘I’ and ‘who’ in these contexts. The attested variants for ‘I’ include *zada*, *zadɨ*, *zad* and *zadːa*, and are never identical to the marking used in possessive predication (see feature @). feature_description: Temporary possessor is a participant that carries a possessum but who does not own it (cf. *I do not have your book with me*). We elicited two contexts: ‘Do not search for your passport, I have it’ and ‘Who has a pen?’. We considered the reaction to the first context as primary evidence. The maps show the forms of pronouns ‘I’ and ‘who’ in these contexts. The attested variants for ‘I’ include *zada*, *zadɨ*, *zad* and *zadːa*, and are never identical to the marking used in possessive predication (see feature @). The second context is probably ambiguous, because some consultants used the form (*halɨχda*) that was used in possessive predication, which we believe suggests “permanent” interpretation of the context with pragmatic inference of having it also here and now, such cases are labeled as OTHER. The attested variants for ‘who’ include *halda* and *haldɨ*.
name: эмираслан

feature_description: We elicited two contexts with internal capability subjects: ‘My brother can swim across the river’ (affirmative) and ‘Rasul couldn't lift this stone’ (negative). The maps show the markers used on the internal capability subjects in these contexts, including *-daː*, *-dːa* and *-da* (attested with only one consultant, in Amsar).

feature_title: Marking of topological relation 'on top of'
feature_description: We elicited the context ‘The butterfly is on the flower’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘flower’. The attested variants include: *-iː* / *-ɨː* / *-ij* / *-ɨ* / *-i* and *-j* (attested only in Ikhrek). We consider *-ij* and *-j* to be phenomena of different nature. We assume the latter to be a separate marker used in Ikhrek, following [@ibragimov2004: 174]. As for the former, it is a phonetic variant of marker *-iː / -ɨː / -ij / -ɨ / -i*, that was attested with only one consultant, in Amsar.
name: Назелле

We assume the latter to be a separate marker used in Ikhrek, following [@ibragimov2004: 174]. As for the former, it is a phonetic variant of marker *-iː / -ɨː / -ij / -ɨ / -i*, that was attested with only one consultant, in Amsar.

long_periods_outside: в 16 лет переехал в Махачкалу, каждый год приезжает, до 21 года в Москве жил
comment: Первая реакция: барийахдыгыр (мусара сахъушури шикил' барийахдыгыр), затем ее отрицает "это то что, она висит". Потом сказал, что нужно барийадыгыр и барийа:ла, потом сказал, что барийадыгыр значит за стеной, потом сказал, что оно же значит "со стены" (т. е. то, что нам нужно...). Барийигыр - через стену (Барийигыр гуьлле егъипы кивихъыри - пуля прошла стену и попала). Барийахды - "на стене". Сувахдыгыр не идет?? Очень запутанно, поэтому кодирую только барийа:ла.

feature_title: Lexical item for the concept ‘cattle shed’
feature_description: We elicited the word for ‘cattle shed’ in the context ‘Cow is in the cattle shed’. The noun was elicited in the inessive. On the map, the stems of the lexical items are shown rather than their full forms in the context. The stems are not necessarily actual oblique stems, but rather labels that represent the lexemes. The lexemes for ‘cattle shed’ are the following: *tawli-* / *towli-* (attested in Myukhrek and Dzhilikhur) and *wixʲ-* (attested elsewhere).

To see the differences in case marking observed in this context, see @feature.

feature_description: The map shows whether the form of the attributive (possessor) noun depends on the case of the head noun (agreement in obliqueness). We elicited three contexts: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (the head noun ‘knife’ is in the nominative and belongs to Gender 4), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (the head noun ‘knife’ is in an oblique case and belongs to Gender 4), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (the head noun ‘dog’ is in the nominative and belongs to Gender 3). In Ikhrek and Khnov, the first contexts shows the attributive suffix *-d* (*šuˤ-d kantʼ* brother-ATTR knife;), and -dɨ in the two other contexts *-dɨ* (*šuˤ-dɨ kantʼi-fan* brother-ATTR knife.OBL-COMIT; *šuˤ-dɨ χij* brother-ATTR dog). In other dialects the suffix *-dɨ* is used in all contexts. In [tairova2010] it is claimed that the same two variants of the attributive suffix are distributed depending on the gender and number of the head in Myukhrek; no details are given as to the case of the head. We cannot directly confirm this based on our data, because, for Myukhrek, the three contexts come from different consultants, so Myukhrek is not shown on the map. However, if we merge the data coming from all consultants, Myukhrek does group not with Khnov and Ikhrek but with the other dialects; and does not confirm Tairova's (2010) account.
name: Лейла
stimuli: Нож брата. Я зарезал овцу ножом брата. Собака брата
answer: шуд кант1. шуд кант1икван. шуд тыла

In other dialects the suffix *-dɨ* is used in all contexts. In [tairova2010] it is claimed that the same two variants of the attributive suffix are distributed depending on the gender and number of the head in Myukhrek; no details are given as to the case of the head. We cannot directly confirm this based on our data, because, for Myukhrek, the three contexts come from different consultants, so Myukhrek is not shown on the map. However, if we merge the data coming from all consultants, Myukhrek does group not with Khnov and Ikhrek but with the other dialects; and does not confirm Tairova's (2010) account.

We elicited three contexts: ‘(my) brother's knife’ (the head noun ‘knife’ is in the nominative and belongs to Gender 4), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother's knife’ (the head noun ‘knife’ is in an oblique case and belongs to Gender 4), ‘(my) brother's dog’ (the head noun ‘dog’ is in the nominative and belongs to Gender 3). In Ikhrek and Khnov, the first contexts shows the attributive suffix *-d* (*šuˤ-d kantʼ* brother-ATTR knife;), and -dɨ in the two other contexts *-dɨ* (*šuˤ-dɨ kantʼi-fan* brother-ATTR knife.OBL-COMIT; *šuˤ-dɨ χij* brother-ATTR dog). In other dialects the suffix *-dɨ* is used in all contexts. In [tairova2010] it is claimed that the same two variants of the attributive suffix are distributed depending on the gender and number of the head in Myukhrek; no details are given as to the case of the head. We cannot directly confirm this based on our data, because, for Myukhrek, the three contexts come from different consultants, so Myukhrek is not shown on the map. However, if we merge the data coming from all consultants, Myukhrek does group not with Khnov and Ikhrek but with the other dialects; and does not confirm Tairova's (2010) account.
